Award.AwardTitle: DCL:HSI Course Based Research Experiences in STEM Education at a two-year HSI College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support changes in science teaching for all students at Santa Rosa Junior College. The investigators will incorporate student-centered teaching practices that increase student motivation and interest in learning and improve laboratory instruction in biology, chemistry, environmental science, geology, math, and physics. These improvements will leverage the CUREnet project, which was previously funded by the NSF, therefore increasing the impact of that investment. The project will improve instruction for non-science majors, increasing the scientific literacy of the general population. Because the college is a Hispanic-Serving institution, the project will also promote the broader participation of Hispanic students majoring in the sciences.

The goals of this project are to shift from traditional, faculty-centered instruction to evidence-based, student-centered practices. The focus on courses that serve both STEM majors and non-STEM majors will broaden the STEM workforce and improve STEM literacy for all students. Project evaluation will examine the development of students' scientific self-identity and impacts on students' academic performance. This project will generate evidence regarding the impacts on student learning due to a research-rich, student-centered, problem-based learning STEM curriculum; how students develop scientific self-identity; the factors that convince non-STEM students to switch to STEM majors; and how faculty members from multiple disciplines form a cohesive professional learning community that collaborates productively at a Hispanic-serving community college.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research supports the benefits of undergraduate research experiences such as internships in success and retention of students, particularly in underrepresented groups. Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) are proposed as opportunities for students to do research and projects with broad applications in their STEM classes. Could CUREs allow students access to the benefits of the research and internship experience? Many students do not have either the free time, or cultural capital to make the connections to get internships, particularly in a community college. At SRJC,  30% of the students are the first in their family to go to college and 40% are Latinx.

Over a 3 year periodn  SRJC implemented CUREs in 14 different STEM classes; both for STEM majors and non-major. They included courses in agriculture, biology, chemistry, computer science, economics, environmental science, mathematics, microbiology and physics. Data was collected on student success, defined as the percentage of students completing the course with a C or better.  In addition, at the beginning and end of the semester student in both CURE and comparable Non-CURE courses were given surveys that assessed a student’s risk of dropping out of a scientific career path. 

The results of this project were very encouraging. For first generation students, 91% finished with a ‘C’ or better in CURE courses, compared to 83% in comparable Non-CURE courses. The same pattern was seen in Latinx students (90% with ‘C’ or better in CURE courses, 85% in Non-CURE) and women (94% in CURE vs. 90% in Non-CURE). The results from the student surveys were more mixed.  Some of the key indicators for student persistence in STEM fields showed significant gains for the CURE students, while other indicators did not.

Given that the sample size for CURE students was 730 and 236 for Non-CURE students, these results should be seen as exploratory rather than definitive. Nevertheless, these are very encouraging results, as the data indicate some of the most vulnerable members of STEM classes are benefiting from CURE projects; women, first generation college students and Latinx students.   More work needs to be done, such as expanding the Non-CURE comparison group and tracking these students as they continue their academic careers at their transfer institutions
